column19: sound synthesis, live coding, music information retrieval and machine learning
column43: Somewhat disorienting, but pleasant at the same time
column44: There was no specific requirement to collaborate, so I don't think there was much of that, perhaps most siginicantly when my collaborator asked me to make some noise when she was drawing a trajectory
column45: The controllers were fine, it just took a while for me personally to get used to it.
column46: I would love to use an interface like this.
column47: There could be alternative modes for trajectory drawing, like interpolation between points rather than dragging. Also the voice controlled volume should be editable, I am not sure if it is in this implementation.

column43: Felt this was a novel way to mix a track. Interesting to try and parameterise space as part of the composition. Although this was a useful creative tool, maybe not classified as "making music",  rather could be considered "engineering music" for space.
column44: The medium and interface both pose an interesting means for collaboration. Through exploration and understanding of the space and the tasks, there were new ways to attempt to collaborate. During this task, attempted a few different strategies to achieve this: either through shared collaboration in building the trajectory, or remote collaboration, i.e. one person building the trajectory, another person managing the tracks on the UI.
column45: VR presents a novel medium. Embodiment in space is something that has previously not been utilised much in music production and this presents new possibilities for musicians and engineers.
column46: This sort of interface might be useful when mixing a track specifically for spatial audio systems, i.e. if it is being rendered binaurally or using ambisonics. Would be interesting to hear it played back within a physical space.
column47: Finer control over the trajectory space, making it easier to modify and delete trajectories. More musical possibilities, i.e (spatial) automation of more effects to change the existing music's sonic qualities.

column19: Digital music processing, music production, sound design, automatic mixing, semantic music, studio technology
column43: I thought it was pretty cool. Nice to explore new spaces, and lots of oportunity - I feel there is some missing functionality and some time getting use to the medium.
column44: I felt it was a really nice organic opportunity
column45: They are a little clunky, but that is nothing to do with the task, and more to do with avaliable tech
column46: I think it has some excellent oportunities as a prototype. The scope for collaborative spatial audio mixing with detailed tactility of control is significant - There is however, considerable scope for future development
column47: Greater functionality, easier menu options/less menus, more processing control, perhaps with automation curves controlled by paths. The interaction with some menus was a little clunky, and the z plane moving objects was unreliable

column19: I have done music tech MA and doing PhD in music tech research
column43: I found it unusual, not too good or bad. especially because there were so many controls and views to manage at once.
column44: I felt it was good to have someone else around to advise and get feedback from - encouragement or otherwise.
column45: Headset felt great, I was not comfortable with the controllers when it came to using the D-pad, as my hand could never be positioned well to use them adaptively.
column46: Once one becomes familiar with it, I imagine it would be incredibly useful for 3D sound
column47: I would like to see the rendering improve, and stronger dynamics in volume. There was no point where I felt anything was as loud as I wanted it to be

column43: somewhat confusing at first especially since this was a new medium to work with. Hovever it was fun experience overall
column45: fine to use, once trained on it
column46: not sure what you mean, maybe as a part of a collaborative music making session
column47: ease of use and minimum training requirements

column43: Not sure if we should call it making music. I guess I felt more like conreoling some paramiters.
column44: I really enjoy the collaborative aspect, much more than expected!
column45: Really well done! Even if there is a lot to learn, I got into the thing somehow naturally.
column46: Composition (electroacoustic music and, hopefully, DEM), audio for cinema or similar, audio for public or private transport (e.g. cars, trains, etc)
column47: I would try the opposite situation: reduce the overall thing to 3 basic interactive elements (thus also giving less control to the user) in order to compare to the current version and better understand what is really needed and what can be improoved

column43: Interesting! I'm usually not concerned with spatial audio, mono is enough for my music :-) So it's not a tool that I really need. But I can see the benefits of VR for spatial audio.
column44: It was nice collaborating, but it wasn't clear whats the point of the system: collaborative music making or spatial audio mixing?
column45: Generally I liked the way the controller were used. I think there are many things that can improve in terms of the menues and what goes in a menu and what goes as a virtual object.
column46: As said before, I'm not really into that sort of stuff. So I don't see myself using something like that for actual music making.
column47: It depends on the goal. If it's a DAW replacement it needs many many missing features (editing, FX, automation, etc). If it should integrate with a DAW the interface can be more minimalistic and concentrate only on the spatial properties (drop the reverb send, level, mutes, etc.). If it's an insperational tool it can be simpler and more opinionated.

column43: It felt quite natural after a period of adjustment. In terms of making music it was limiting in certain ways due to the simple nature of the interface but in terms of taking control of spatial aspects of the music, it was brilliant.
column44: I enjoyed it more when collaborating. One person being able to take charge of the actions while another viewed from afar and gave feedback on the task. I also enjoyed the conversational aspect of the task.
column45: Ok, I'm not a huge fan of VR tech but I can't think of another way of authoring spatial audio content that gives such control of the movements of the sound.
column47: There are many small things that would make the interaction more natural but in terms of big useful controls that could be added a couple of things sprung to mind. The ability to move full trajectories once they are drawn. The ability to merge between listening positions (I suppose here I'm thinking more about using this as a tool for composing fixed medium acousmatic music rather than as a VR audio authoring tool).

column43: Knowing not much about music, I feel like it was a great way of creating and editing sound. Being able to visualise your sound in a 3D space make it easier for me to understund how it work.
column44: As I am quite shy, I felt a little bit stressed to talk but the ability to create a soundtrack with someone is amazing and the communication was working really well. The ability to control what someone else is doing and to collaborate to affect the other player objects is great and made the experience really fun and easier to navigate.
column45: I think the control make sense and work well but it does take quite some time to get use to it.
column46: This can be a great way for anyone who is interested in immersive technology and music. A lot of people want to create sound but don't have the ability to do so. I think this is the future for those peoples.
column47: For me, the main thing which I found it hard to cope with was the fact that your controller have to touch the ui button to click I would maybe add 50cm/80cm click distance. For the interactions I which you were able to add more than one object on each line you created and maybe have a little bit more control on the volume as you can't always hear what you just created.

column43: I felt it to be innovate and having lots of potential
column44: With this specifc task it may have been easier partaking it as an individual but with other tasks eg giving certain users certain tasks this could be greatly enhanced.
column45: It is dependant on the spatial nature of the sound, in order for it to benefit being in VR there needs to be 360 element to the sound.
column46: Remixing and potentially composing audio with multiple composers, it may also have some theraputic benefits in musical therapy etc and some use in the disco nightclub domain.
column47: the bringing objects nearer functionailty did not work great for me, it would obviously be good to have some form of directory and be able to switch the sounds out for other ones, being able to interact with more than just amplitude through voice or recorded sound, if actual digital audio could be recorded someone could play a guitar piano or drumline for example and other users could manipulate it shortly after.

column17: I write and produce commercial, underground and sync music
column43: This brought an excitment to the process. The limitations and repetitivness of a daw/ mixing console are my ususal process so this felt fresh and creative.
column44: The server has an issue when collaberating but until that it felt intuative and fun.Co0llaberationb felt straight forward
column45: Loved them. Very easy to work with and accurate
column46: I think I could genuinly use this in conjuntion with more traditional methods. I love the idea if hopping into the virtual world to play with elements in the space and it feels alot more imersive than atmos software plugins.
column47: I think when in collaberation mode there could be some way to isolate audio input per user. This would allow multiple lanes to be created in tandem rather than turn about.

column43: Really impressive.  It opened up new ways to think about the space that you listen to music which in regular day to day music production isn't as crucial as it is in this environment. Id feel you would be able to make music much more immersive.
column44: Easy.  There was clear communication between Kyle and I and didn't feel restrictive in any way.  Much the same as in a normal non VR environment.
column45: Once I had my head around getting to the various menu's it was very intuitive.  Initial learning curve of a say 5 minutes... but after that I felt fairly confident navigating to different sections of the controls.
column46: I would really enjoy doing this more. Often when making music in a regualr space, you zone out and are focusing on things that are not tangible.   to make the audio a tangeble object to physically play around with, something that has forever been various shapes in my mind, makes it a really exciting prospect.
column47: Acuracy is the one thing that might be difficult at this stage.  That said, with a bit more time to feel very comfortable in the space, you could argue that you would be able to be much more accurate with spacial audio. It's timing and rythmic automation might be harder to get that accuracy.
